The novel acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] was prepared and characterized by FT-IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, DEPT-135, LC-Mass, and elemental analysis techniques. It was examined as a catalyst for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methane derivatives at ambient temperature, and an important advantage was that it required only short reaction times. The crude bis-indolyl methane products could be purified by a simple recrystallization process, avoiding time-consuming chromatography. The catalyst was reusable, and even after five runs, an insignificant loss in the activity of the catalyst was observed. The chemical integrity of the recovered catalyst after the fifth run was confirmed by FT-IR, 1H NMR, and Mass analysis. This reaction has a high value of the environmental factor (E). Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] Imidazolium Bis-indolyl methanes Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The development of efficient and recyclable catalysts is a challenging task in organic synthesis, especially when wider efficiency and environmental factors are considered. Literature survey reveals that many researchers are focusing their research extensively on green catalysts and green solvents for the synthesis of organic compounds [1–3]. Ionic liquids are salts composed of cations and anions that appear in the liquid phase at room temperature or below 100 °C, and they play a versatile role in catalysis [4–6]. Ionic liquids can have an edge over conventional catalysts used in organic synthetic work because of their unique properties, such as low vapor pressure, high thermal stability, high polarity, low volatility, non-inflammability, good conductivity, and high solvation capacity [7–9]. These versatile properties make them excellent catalysts for various organic reactions such as Michael addition [10,11], Knoevenagel condensation [12–15], Aldol condensation [16,17], and the Claisen-Schmidt reaction [18–21]. In particular, acidic ionic liquid catalysts exhibit excellent performance as a result of their non-corrosiveness, recyclability, and reusability [22–24]. Among heterocyclic compounds, indole and its derivatives have been extensively studied compounds due to their biological properties, including antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, cytotoxic, anti-leishmanial, antibacterial, and antifungal activity [25–27]. Bis-indolyl methane compounds contain indole as a core structural unit, and can be isolated from bioactive alkaloids of terrestrial and marine origin [28]. Bis-indolyl methane exhibits a range of anti-cancer activities, such as inhibition of bladder and cervical cell carcinoma cancer growth, and anti-leukemic and anti-tumorigenic activity, and has potential use against colon cancer and induction of apoptosis in prostate cancer [29,30]. In addition, reduction of the severity of symptoms of fibromyalgia and anti-HIV properties is a significant medicinal application of bis-indolyl methane [31]. Owing to these extensive biological properties and potential applications in the drug discovery field, the development of new synthetic and catalytic methods to synthesize functionalized bis-indolyl methane compounds is a hot topic for researchers and it is also an excellent showcase for green chemistry applications. Literature survey reveals that several acidic catalysts have already been reported for synthesizing bis-indolyl methane such as amino sulfonic acid [32], HCP@CH2Br [33], silica gel fused with Lewis acids [34], thiamine hydrochloride [35], diammonium hydrogen phosphate [36], dodecylsulphonic acid [37], metal hydrogen sulfates [38], 12-tungstophosphoric acid [39], [FeCl2(±)BINAM] complex [40], α-chymotrypsin [41], [Et3NH][H2PO4] [42], BBSI-HSO4 [43], multi-SO3H IL [44], ethyl ammonium nitrate [45], [DABCO-H][HSO4] [46], [hmim][HSO4] [47], {Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-SO3H/HCl} [48], FeCl3.6H2O [49], InCl3 [50] and boric acid [51]. However, these catalysts and the protocols using them have several disadvantages, such as longer reaction time, difficulty in isolation of products, high temperature, complex synthetic pathways, halide and metal-containing catalysts, loss of catalytic activity, low solvation, and formation of impurities in the products. These limitations could be overcome by synthesizing an eco-friendly and recyclable catalyst via a simple process; we report a safe and halide-free acidic ionic liquid, [BEMIM][HSO4]. The catalytic activities of the ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] were investigated for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methane derivatives at ambient temperature. The most important advantage of this method is that it requires very little time to synthesize bis-indolyl methane derivatives. These derivatives were purified using a simple recrystallization technique instead of tedious column chromatography. Furthermore, the recyclability and chemical stability of the acidic ionic liquid catalyst [BEMIM][HSO4] were evaluated. 2 Results and discussion First, we synthesized a new acidic ionic liquid, 3-(2-Benzyloxy ethyl)-1-methyl imidazole hydrogen sulfate [BEMIM][HSO4], in high yield, as depicted in Scheme 1. The structure of the synthesized acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] was established using various characterization tools such as FTIR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, DEPT-135, Mass spectrometry, and elemental analysis. The corresponding spectra of the synthesized acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] are incorporated in the ESI (Figs. S1–S6). 2.1 FT-IR analysis The FT-IR spectra of the acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] are presented in Fig. S1, which demonstrate the functional groups present in the catalyst. The FT-IR spectrum of the acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] showed the appearance of a strong absorption band around 3417 cm−1 and 1168 cm−1, attributed to O-H and SO stretching vibrations, respectively, which also confirmed the exchange of bromide anion by the [HSO4] anion. The bands at 1574 cm−1 and 1454 cm−1 were assigned to the C-C and C-N stretching vibrations of the imidazole ring, respectively. The absorption peaks at 1053 and 852 cm−1 were assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the ether functional group (-C-O-C). 2.2 1H NMR analysis The structure of acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] was confirmed from its 1H NMR spectra. In the 1H NMR spectrum recorded in the D2O solution (Fig. S2), the deshielded –NCH3 group appeared as a singlet peak at δ 3.77 ppm. The triplets appeared upfield at δ 3.83 ppm for the –NCH2 group and at δ 4.27 ppm for the –OCH2 group, whereas the methylene proton of the –OCH2-Ar group exhibited a singlet at δ 4.47 ppm. The aromatic protons of the aryl and imidazole rings were observed downfield at δ 7.22–8.52 ppm. 2.3 13C NMR analysis From the 13C NMR spectrum of acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] (Fig. S3), the chemical shift of the deshielded –NCH3 group signal was found to be δ 35.70 ppm. The chemical shift was assigned at δ 49.21 ppm and δ 67.84 ppm corresponds to -NCH2 group and -OCH2 group correspondingly whereas the peak was obtained at δ 72.71 ppm for the methylene carbon of –OCH2-Ar group. The carbon signals of the aryl and imidazole rings were assigned in the range δ 122.37–136.80 ppm. 2.4 DEPT-135 analysis DEPT-135 analysis revealed negative signals for methylene carbon, while positive signals for methyl and methine carbon were recorded for the acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] (Fig. S4). Negative signals were attributed at δ 49.27 ppm, δ 67.32 ppm, δ 72.66 ppm for -NCH2, -OCH2, and -OCH2-Ar groups of methylene carbon. A chemical shift of the positive signal was observed at δ 35.72 ppm for the -NCH3 carbon. All methine carbon signals of the aryl and imidazole rings were present in the range of δ 122.35–136.02 ppm. 2.5 Mass analysis Analysis of mass measurements revealed a representative molecular ion mass (m/z) peak for the cation (Fig. S5) at 217.71, which is well matched with its theoretical value. In addition, the molecular ion mass (m/z) peak of the anion (Fig. S6) was displayed at 96.90, which was designated as the displacement of bromide to the HSO4 anion. The mass (m/z) of both the cation and anion specified the complete formation of the targeted acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4]. Once the formation of desired acidic ionic liquid is confirmed, its applicability as a catalyst for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methane derivatives was evaluated ( Scheme 2). For the synthesis of bis-indolyl methane, indole (2 mmol) and 4-Cl benzaldehyde (1 mmol) were used as model substrates to optimize the standard reaction conditions. The preliminary experiments were checked under solvent-free conditions with 0.3 mmol and 1.0 mmol catalyst loading at ambient temperature yielding a very low amount of bis-indolyl methane 8f in 60 min ( Table 1, entries 1,2). The same reaction was carried out using a 2.0 mmol catalyst loading at 50 °C, which implies a slight improvement in the yield of the product (65%) in 30 min (Table 1, entry 3). Furthermore, the same reaction was carried out using [BEMIM][HSO4] as a solvent (5 ml) at three different temperatures 27 °C, 50 °C and 85 °C to yield 80%, 85%, and 90% of bis-indolyl methane 8f with a decrease in the completion time of 30 min, 20 min, and 10 min respectively. Next, the catalyst performance was investigated by varying the amount of catalyst in polar solvents such as MeOH, EtOH, CH3CN, and their mixtures with water (MeOH: H2O (1:1) and EtOH: H2O (1:1) at ambient temperature. The results showed that bis-indolyl methane 8f was obtained in satisfactory to excellent yields with decrease in the time for completion of the reaction (Table 1, entries 7–14). By evaluating the results of entries 7–14 from Table 1, it was noted that the leading result of the conversion of bis-indolyl methane 8f was observed in methanol solvent with 0.5 mmol amount of catalyst charging at 27 °C, which yielded 95% of the product, and the reaction was completed in 5 min (Table 1, entry 9). The same reaction was carried out at 50 °C and 64 °C and the reaction is completed in 5 min with the isolation of 95% and 94% bis-indolyl methane 8f (Table 1, entries 15–16). The above results confirmed that an increase in temperature had no effect on the time of completion of the reaction or product yield. At lower concentration of the catalyst the model reaction was performed in methanol at 27 °C, which results in 90% of the product, and the reaction completion time was increased to 10 min (Table 1, entry 17). In the TON study of the catalyst, the reaction was carried out using a lower concentration of 10 mol% of the [BEMIM][HSO4] catalyst at 27 °C and 64 °C in methanol, which afforded excellent product yields; however, the reaction completion time increased to 30 min, and 20 min, respectively (Table 1, entries 18,19). Furthermore, the scope of the different counter cations for the acidic ionic liquid catalysts, such as [hmim][HSO4] and [bnmim][HSO4], was evaluated to construct the bis-indolyl methane 8f compound. Both the acidic ionic liquids [hmim][HSO4] and [bnmim][HSO4] were prepared by following the literature procedure [52,53]. The acidic ionic liquids [BEMIM][HSO4], [hmim][HSO4] and [bnmim][HSO4] contain identical hydrogen sulfate [HSO4] counter anions while 3-(2-benzyloxyethyl)-1-methyl imidazolium [BEMIM], 1-hexyl-3-methyl imidazolium [hmim], 1-benzyl-3-methyl imidazolium [bnmim] have different counter cations. Keeping in mind the results of 0.5 mmol and 10 mol% concentration of [BEMIM][HSO4] catalyst in methanol at 27 °C, a model reaction using the different counter cations acidic ionic liquid [hmim][HSO4] and [bnmim][HSO4] as catalysts with 0.5 mmol and 10 mol% concentration correspondingly in methanol at room temperature was conducted and the results are tabulated in Table 1 (Entries 20–23). The different acidic ionic liquid catalysts [hmim][HSO4] and [bnmim][HSO4] afforded excellent yields of bis-indolyl methane product 8f, but it took longer time for completion of reaction than that of [BEMIM][HSO4]. The efficiency of the acidic ionic liquid catalyst [BEMIM] [HSO4] was observed to be higher than that of the different acidic ionic liquid catalysts [hmim][HSO4] and [bnmim][HSO4]. This might be due to the presence of ethereal functionality in the counter cation of [BEMIM] [HSO4], which interact with polar reaction medium and enhances the catalytic activity of [BEMIM] [HSO4]. The acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] showed comparable catalytic performance for both the 10 mol% and 0.5 mmol concentration and afforded approximately the same yield of bis-indolyl methane product 8f. Consequently, from the viewpoint of ease of catalyst recovery and shorter reaction time, a higher catalyst concentration (0.5 mmol) was used for further optimization. Moreover, the influence of different solvents on the model reaction was screened by employing a 0.5 mmol [BEMIM][HSO4] catalyst at ambient temperature, and the results are summarized in Table 2. First, the model reaction was carried out under neat conditions, which formed 25% of the product in 1 h, whereas the same reaction yielded trace amounts of the product in 1 h using a non-polar solvent such as n-hexane (Table 2, entries 1, 2). The reaction with aprotic solvents such as toluene and dichloromethane afforded 30% and 40% of the product in 1 h, respectively (Table 2, entries 3–4). Furthermore, polar aprotic solvents such as acetone, ethyl acetate, THF, and CH3CN afforded satisfactory to good yields of bis-indolyl methane in 1 hr (Table 2, entries 5–8), while polar protic solvents such as methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, MeOH:H2O (1:1), EtOH:H2O (1:1), and water afforded satisfactory to excellent yields with a reduction in the reaction completion time, up to 5 min (Table 2, entries 9–14). Based on the above solvent screening data, it is noteworthy that the catalytic efficacy of the catalyst was enhanced in methanol, a highly polar protic solvent, which gave a higher conversion of bis-indolyl methane (95%) within a few minutes (Table 2, entry 10). With the appropriate reaction conditions in hand, the generality and flexibility of the protocol were scrutinized by altering the substituted aldehydes in the reaction. The reactions of substituted aryl aldehydes and heteroaryl aldehydes were performed with indole in methanol at 25–30 °C. The desired bis-indolyl methane compounds (8a–r) were isolated in 85–98% yield within a very short span (2–10 min) of reaction time ( Table 3, entries 1–18). Table 3 shows that the reactions of arylaldehydes containing electron withdrawing groups (-Cl, -NO2) afforded the corresponding bis-indolyl methane compounds in excellent yield (92–98%) while the electron donating moieties (-OH, -N(CH3)2, -OCH3, -CH3) at different positions also afforded excellent yield (90–98%) of the products. The heteroarylaldehydes such as thiophene 2-carboxyaldehyde, furfuraldehyde, and pyridine 2-carboxyaldehyde yield bis-indolyl methane compounds 8e, 8l and 8r in 85%, 87% and 88% yields, respectively, with a minute increase in the reaction time. The synthesized bis-indolyl methane compounds (8a-8r) were characterized from their melting points, spectroscopic analysis (IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and elemental analysis) by comparison with data reported in the literature [41,46,48,52]. A representative compound, 3,3′ bis (indolyl)-(2,5-dimethoxyphenyl) methane (8d), was thoroughly explored using spectroscopic data. The FT-IR spectrum of compound 8d showed a characteristic absorption peak for N-H stretching at 3400 cm−1. 1H NMR analysis revealed that the two methoxy (-OCH3) group protons appeared as singlets at δ 3.62 and δ 3.78 ppm whereas the typical methine (-CH) proton showed a singlet at δ 6.33 ppm. The aromatic proton signals were observed at δ 6.67–7.43 ppm while two -NH protons were observed as downfield singlet at δ 7.87. In the 13C NMR spectrum, signals at δ 32.15 ppm for methine carbon and two methoxy group C signals appeared at δ 55.48 and δ 56.59 ppm respectively. The aromatic C signals were observed in the range of δ 110.63–153.42 ppm. In general, in 1H NMR spectra of all characterized bis-indolyl methane compounds, the −NH proton signals appeared as a singlet in the region of 7.87–9.91 ppm whereas Ar–CH proton signals were observed in the region of 6.63–8.21 ppm. The characteristic –CH proton appeared as a singlet in the region of 5.82–6.33 ppm confirming product formation, and the leftover proton signals were observed in the expected regions. In the 13C NMR spectra of the products, the methine carbon signals were observed in the region of 32.15–39.99 ppm whereas the aromatic carbon signals appeared in the region of 110.63–160.32 ppm, confirming the construction of bis-indolyl methane compounds. Based on a literature study [45,56], a proposed mechanism for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methanes over the [BEMIM][HSO4] catalyst is depicted in Scheme 3. Both the cationic and anionic sites of acidic ionic liquid activate the carbonyl group of aldehydes 7. The nucleophilic attack of indole 6 on activated carbonyl compound 7 leads to the formation of intermediate 9 which upon further dehydration generates intermediate 10. Further, the nucleophilic attack of the second molecule of indole 6 on intermediate 10 gave rise to an adduct 11, which undergoes aromatization to give the targeted bis-indolyl methane compound 8. Moreover, the environmental factor (E Factor) of the reaction is a useful parameter to describe the process as green chemistry; hence, evaluation for bis-indolyl methane 8f using the formula E Factor=[(Total mass of raw materials - the total mass of product) /Mass of product] gives a value of 0.05, close to the ideal value of 0. This indicates that the reaction generated the least amount of waste product. The recyclability of the catalyst [BEMIM][HSO4] for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methane compound 8o under optimized conditions was evaluated ( Table 4). The recovered catalyst was repeatedly used to run the same model reaction under the same reaction conditions. The obtained results indicated that the product showed a consistent but small decrease in the yield up to the fifth run, which was due to a slight loss of amount of catalyst as well as a decrease in the acidity of the catalyst [BEMIM][HSO4]. Furthermore, the chemical stability of the catalyst after the fifth cycle was scrutinized by FT-IR, 1H NMR, and mass spectrometry (Figs. S7–S9) and the analytical data were compared with those of the fresh catalyst. The FT-IR analysis of the recovered catalyst showed absorption peaks at 3389, 1574, 1454, 1175, 1069, and 850 cm−1, with retention of position and intensity comparable to that of the fresh catalyst, indicating that no change occurred in the functional groups of the catalyst. In the 1HNMR characterization of the recovered catalyst, the signals obtained at δ 3.68, 3.74, 4.17, 4.38 ppm and 7.12–8.43 ppm region for methyl, methylene, and aromatic protons, respectively, were closely related to the fresh catalyst proton signals, implying that no structural change in the ionic liquid occurred even after the fifth cycle. Finally, mass measurement of the recovered catalyst revealed a molecular ion mass (m/z) peak for the cation at 217.71, which is equivalent to the mass of the fresh catalyst, indicating that there was no structural fragmentation of the ionic liquid. The analytical results for the fresh and recovered catalysts are tabulated in Table 5 , which shows that there is no significant change in their analytical values; thus, it can be concluded that the catalyst is highly stable up at least up to the fifth recycle. Furthermore, it is competent and can be reused under optimized conditions (Figs. S7–S9). The tabulated results clearly show that the acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] has an edge over all the other catalysts in terms of reaction time, yield of bis-indolyl methane, efficiency, and recyclability ( Table 6). The concentration of the acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] in the reaction may enhance the acidic character, which increases the catalytic activity of the catalyst. The combination of high catalyst concentration [BEMIM][HSO4] in methanol as the polar reaction medium resulted in high catalytic performance, and the reaction was completed in a shorter time (Entry 11). In Table 6 , previously reported catalysts (Entries 1–10) used under solvent-free conditions and in low-polarity solvent media seem to have moderate catalytic activity, and longer time to complete the reaction. In addition, our new strategy of bis-indolyl methane synthesis is convenient compared with the other mentioned protocols in terms of the use of inexpensive commercial solvents, halide-free efficient catalysts, shorter reaction times, ambient conditions, ease of catalyst recovery, excellent product yields, and product purification by a simple recrystallization process instead of column chromatographic purification. 3 Experimental 3.1 General All the chemicals and solvents were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, Loba Chemicals, and were used without further purification. The melting points were uncorrected. The progress of all reactions was checked by TLC. FTIR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer FTIR-1600 spectrophotometer using KBr. Analysis of 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and DEPT-135 spectra were obtained using a Bruker Avance (400 and 500 MHz) spectrometer with CDCl3 D2O, DMSO-d6 solutions and TMS as the internal standard. Chemical shifts (δ) were reported in ppm. Mass spectra were observed with a Waters Q-TOF micro mass spectrometer by electro spray ionization (ESI). 3.2 Synthesis of [BEMIM][HSO4] acidic ionic liquid catalyst (5) (Scheme 1) A mixture of 1- methyl imidazole (1) (25 mmol) and 2- benzyloxy ethyl bromide (2) (25 mmol) was added at 25–30 °C into a single neck 250 ml round bottom flask. The reactants were heated between 80 and 85 °C temperatures for 5 hrs, resulting in the formation of a viscous, thick oily mass. The oily mass was washed and decanted with ethyl acetate (4 ×30 ml) at 25–30 °C to ensure that the mixture is free from unreacted reactants. The thick oily mass obtained was degassed under vacuum at 80–85 °C, resulting in the formation of a viscous yellowish oily intermediate ionic liquid [BEMIM][Br] (3). The intermediate ionic liquid [BEMIM][Br] (3) and 30 ml of ethanol were added into a flask and the reaction mixture was stirred continuously at the temperature 25–30 °C for 15–20 min to obtain a clear homogeneous solution. A stoichiometric amount of conc. H2SO4 (4) was slowly added to the clear solution at 25–30 °C, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 3–4 hrs at 50–55 °C to carry out the anion metathesis. Then, the reaction mixture was concentrated under vacuum at 55–60 °C to obtain a viscous oily residue, which was washed with 4 × 25 ml ethyl acetate. Finally, the oily residual mass was degassed under vacuum at 80–85 °C, affording a viscous, light brown acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] (5) in 97.0% yield. 3.3 General procedure for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methanes (8a-8r) In a single neck 25 ml flask, 5 ml of methanol, indole 6 (2 mmol), and aldehyde 7a–r (1 mmol) were added at 25–30 °C. The acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] (0.5 mmol) catalyst was added and the reaction mixture were stirred at 50 °C until completion of the reaction, as shown by TLC using pet ether:ethyl acetate (8:2) as the solvent system. After the completion of the reaction, the mixture was quenched in crushed ice with constant stirring. The precipitated product was isolated by filtration through Whatman filter paper, and the crude solid was recrystallized in 80% ethanol to afford pure bis-indolyl methane 8a–r. All the synthesized products were confirmed by their melting points, as reported in the literature. Representative derivatives were characterized by FT-IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and elemental analysis. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a novel, highly efficient, halogen-free, recoverable, and reusable catalyst, [BEMIM][HSO4], is reported for the first time, and used for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methane compounds. The use of affordable commercial solvents as reaction media, purification of crude products by recrystallization, excellent yield of the products, chemical stability and recyclability of the catalyst for up to five cycles, mild reaction conditions, and good E factor make the described methodology of promise for application in various chemical and pharmaceutical industries. coredata.dc:description: The novel acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4] was prepared and characterized by FT-IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, DEPT-135, LC-Mass, and elemental analysis techniques. It was examined as a catalyst for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methane derivatives at ambient temperature, and an important advantage was that it required only short reaction times. The crude bis-indolyl methane products could be purified by a simple recrystallization process, avoiding time-consuming chromatography. The catalyst was reusable, and even after five runs, an insignificant loss in the activity of the catalyst was observed. The chemical integrity of the recovered catalyst after the fifth run was confirmed by FT-IR, 1H NMR, and Mass analysis. This reaction has a high value of the environmental factor (E).
coredata.dc:title: Novel acidic ionic liquid [BEMIM][HSO4]: A highly efficient and recyclable catalyst for the synthesis of bis-indolyl methane derivatives
